and as joint executor of my father’s will I received and receipted for a check on the cashier of the Bank of the Metropolis for that sum— I had not time to receive the money at the Bank, but hurried to the house where I expected Charles J. Ingersoll would start again his motion to suspend the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union to take up the Jackson fine bill; but this time the Speaker saved
saved him the trouble of making the motion to choke off the debate on the rules, by deciding that henceforth that debate would only be in order during the morning hour. A decision like most of those of John W. Jones deeply tainted with Slavery— Upon this decision Dr Duncan of Cincinnati took the floor and occupied three fourths of the hour with a plausible but so far as relates to the real point at issue an ambiguous speech— He came out sufficiently clear and explicit against the rule— Assuming the same ground as Hamlin of Maine, John W. Davis of Indiana, and Clingman of North Carolina did yesterday of the Constitutional and unalienable right of petition— But from this he quickly flew off into a bitter invective upon the abolitionists and upon the negro race. Affirming without qualification the inferiority of that race to that of the whites— Insisting that of all countries on the face of the earth Africa was the only one where Christianity after being once introduced has never been able to take root— And alluding in a tone of ridicule and buffoonery to the physical conformation of the negro maintaining that no length of time or change of climate can change their complexion, their woolly head, their flat nose or their crooked leg or splay-foot; and their effluvia. The Slavers were highly delighted with this vulgar slang, and chuckled much when the Doctor pointing directly to me asked what my opinion on this subject was and intimated that I owed it to my own character, and to the country to answer his question— I took no notice of it, and after he concluded his speech he came round to my seat and asked me in a mild and friendly manner if I intended to answer his question— I said yes—but not on this debate, for I considered all that part of his speech as irrelevant to the question before the house, and if I attempted to answer it, I should in three minutes of time be called to order for irrelevancy, and the Speaker would pronounce me out of order for irrelevancy— But that on some proper occasion, I would if the house would let me, answer him to his heart’s content.— He asked in a still more pointed manner a question of Giddings with the intention of injuring him and Henry Clay— Giddings did answer him, sportively, but to his utter confusion— As soon as he finished A. V. Brown of Tennessee took the floor, but the morning hour expired in ten minutes and the house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the Jackson fine bill, which was debated till near 5. O’Clock when the Committee rose and the house adjourned— Douglas of Illinois made an eloquent sophistical speech prodigiously admired by the Slave Democracy of the House— This evening with my wife, Mrs John Adams and her daughter I attended a Concert.

The concert last Evening was for the benefit of the poor, at the Assembly rooms—the old Theatre, in the Louisiana avenue— It was almost entirely Italian music of the recent Operas, closing with the Liberty song of the Puritani, wretchedly performed— An English song of a maniac lover was sung and performed on the piano by an amateur named Drayton, a silly but celebrated novelty to me. Esther Corsini sang two bravuras, with sundry screams and contortions of the face, nearly convulsive— This morning I attended with Isaac H. Adams, public worship, in the Hall of the House of Representatives, where both the chaplains were present, and Mr Tustin preached from 2. Timothy 3.16 [“]All scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reproof, for correction, for instruction in righteousness.” He gave out Watts’s hundredth psalm, and read it by two lines at a time, setting the tune of old hundred after requesting volunteer assistance from the auditory to carry him through— The Sermon was a glorification of the Scriptures, well sustained with the exception that it conceded too much to the infidel scoffer by admitting that there was much to be said on his side of the argument, and laying the main stress of his plea for christianity on the consideration that it is safest to believe— He gave a historical summary of the time at which this epistle to Timothy, and the circumstances under which it was written, and an outline of the general purport of the Letter with some notices of Timothy, the person to whom it was written, and of the intimate and affectionate relations between Paul and him.— After the service was over Mr Tustin came with his colleague Mr Tinsley and introduced him to me, at my seat— And he asked me if I recollected the baptism of a child at Leesburg when I was there with General La Fayette and ex-President Monroe, in August 1825. I said I remembered it well: and that the impression of it was the more vivid on my mind from the fact which I had heard that the child then baptised under circumstances apparently so auspicious, died that same night— He said it was true— On my way home I called and left a card at Mr Slidells house he being not at home— Returning thence I met again Mr Tinsley who read to me a notice which he had just received that Mr Robert Baird would preach at the Presbyterian church at 7 this Evening. I went with Isaac Hull and heard him. Dr Laurie made the prayer— Mr Knox was in the pulpit Mr Bairds text was from Hebrews 13 24. They of Italy salute you and his discourse to Levy a contribution for the Waldenses.

Immediately after the reading of the Journal in the house this morning Thomson of Mississippi moved a suspension of the rules for a motion to cease all debate in Committee of the whole upon the Jackson fine bill, at 4 O’Clock this afternoon, and to take the question on the amendments and report the bill to the house— This is the formula for suppressing all debate, and was carried by yeas and nays 116. to 54. a more than two thirds vote— Thomson then moved his resolution to smother debate, and take the Bill out of Committee at 4 p.m. this afternoon— Pratt of New-York moved as a substitute for Thomsons motion a resolution to stop debate and take the bill out of Committee in two hours, with a long preamble stating that the Legislatures of 17 States representing a population of 15 out of the 17 millions of the People of the United States had demanded the restoration of this fine; and then enumerating one by one the 17 States and the population of each of them and concluding that therefore the debate on this bill should cease in two hours and the question upon it be taken this day— Thompson accepted this as a modification of his own resolution, excepting that he adhered to his own limitation of the time to 4. O’Clock, to which Pratt acceded; and the resolution was carried— Thompson then moved to go into Committee of the whole, and it was done; John W. Davis of Indiana in the chair— Schenk of Ohio had the floor from Saturday, and made an hour speech of unrivaled eloquence in that department of debate which one of the Athenian Orators called the Shears—cutting up the arguments of the adversary— Schenk said little about the first principles involved in this case and not much about the facts, but he did cut up the malignant sycophantic declamation of Kennedy, Weller, Dean and Douglas so that there was scarcely a shred of them left. His manner is cool firm, unhesitating, with conscious mastery of his subject, his voice clear and strong, his elocution neat and elegant, with a swelling vein of sarcastic humour which more than once made the hall ring with shouts of laughter— He had got hold of Douglas, and was shaking him as a bull dog shakes between his teeth a dead rat, when his hour expired and A. V. Brown took the floor, and from that time with the exception of a short quarter of an hour for Severance, the Jackson trumpeters blew till they brayed like Jackasses till 4. They passed the bill and closed the day with a triumphal drunken bout at the Apollo Hall, toasting and crepitating with a cannon in the Street till long after midnight.

The Select Committee on the Resolves of the Legislature of Massachusetts had adjourned to meet this morning at ten in the room of the Committee of Commerce— They gathered one by one, till about half past ten when they formed a quorum; and waited another half hour for Joseph R. Ingersoll who keeps the minutes, and whom I found in Session with the Committee of Ways and Means. The members of our Committee were all present but we found on the mantle piece a scrap of paper which the door keeper of the room desired me to look at— There was written on it Resolved that this room is wanted for the Committee of Commerce, every day except those days when it is occupied by the Naval Committee— This was a mere effusion of petty spite from Holmes, now chairman of the Committee of Commerce; and the manner of notifying us was as ingenious as the Resolution itself was courteous. But it put upon me the responsibility of finding a room for our committee to meet in.— Our meeting this morning was short— Gilmer pressed hard for the question on his resolution that the amendment proposed by the Resolves of the Legislature of Massachusetts ought not to be recommended— I consented to take the question upon my proposed amendment to strike out the word not, and the vote upon it was 6 to 3. against striking out— Giddings Morse and myself only voting for it— I then moved to postpone the question on Gilmer’s Resolution to take up my two Resolutions that the chairman be authorised to move the house for instructions to the Committee to ascertain as far as may be practicable the number of the owners of Slaves and the value of the property in Slaves— The postponement was carried— Gilmer opposed my first resolution on the ground that the Committee, had already by their Commission from the house authority to obtain the information, desired by my Resolution—whereupon I modified my resolution into a motion that the Committee authorise the chairman to obtain this information, which suited Gilmer palate no better than the other proposition— But noon arrived and the Committee adjourned to Thursday morning ten O’Clock— In the house George W Summers took his seat— The first half hour was eliminated as usual, by disorderly motions for preference in business among which was one of D. D. Barnard which I could not prevail on myself to oppose, but which after all he could not carry; and then the whole hour was consumed in chicanery to stave off the discussion of the report on the rules— Dilatory motion after motion wasted time till a motion was made to lay the whole subject on the table—rejected by yeas and naystoBut the hour was gone. The house went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union R. C. Winthrop in the chair, on the references of the Presidents Message— About four the Committee rose and the house adjourned— R. S. Cutts here this eve.

In the National Intelligencer of this morning there was a notice that judge William Cranch my first cousin, the intimate friend of my childhood and youth, now for more than forty years a judge and chief Justice of the United States Circuit Court for the District of Columbia, one of the best of the race of man was by severe illness unable to attend his court, now in Session— At the door of the Patriotic Bank I met his Son William and enquired how he was. He answered in deep dejection that he was very low with a pleurisy fever of which they feared the issue— I asked if I should call at his house, I could see him He answered with some hesitation that he believed I could— I went immediately to his house where I found his Son John and William C. Greenleaf— William Cranch came in while I was there— They thought it best I should not see him, as he was in a wandering state of mind, had been much agitated by a visit from Mr Bulfinch, and his two physicians, Doctors Sewell and May—had recently left him, and directed that he should be kept as quiet as possible— I concluded to call again to morrow, and went over immediately to the Capitol, and having at the Patriotic Bank, entered as Executor of T. B. Johnson, a check from R W Dyer forand as Administrator of my Son John an order on the Hotel company Stock at Frederick Maryland forand received at the Washington Bank 60 dollars for a quarter’s interest due the first of this Month. In the house the Rules were suspended by a vote of more than two thirds to receive undebatable resolutions and calls on the President, and heads of Departments for information— Upwards of two hours were consumed in this process, which I patiently endured knowing that I could now have but one hour a day for the report on the rules, at any rate— As soon as these crudities were digested I called for the business of the morning hour and the jugglery commenced to choke off the consideration of the report— The motion pending was to postpone the consideration of the report for two weeks, which the Speaker had decided could be decided by a bare majority of votes. Winthrop now moved an amendment; that it should be made the special order of that and every succeeding day till the report should be gone through— The Speaker decided that this amendment would require a vote of two thirds— But Clinton withdrew his motion to postpone: A. V. Brown, occupied the remainder of the hour in a speech for the recommitment and instructions— The house then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon the references of the Presidents message and adjourned about 4— Fall of Snow.

Going to the Capitol this morning I called at judge Cranch’s house to enquire how he was, and if I could see him; and was told that he was no better than yesterday and was asleep— I met the Committee on the Resolves of the Legislature of Massachusetts in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, of which, yesterday I had by negotiation with the Speaker and the door keeper procured the use for the Committee— All the members of the Committee were present: but Mr Morse was at least an hour tardy— My modified motion that the chairman be instructed to enquire and ascertain as far as may be practicable the number of owners of Slaves in the several States and territories of this Union and in the district of Columbia, was earnestly debated. Gilmer struggling to strangle it by a motion of amendment proposing to request the chairman, and each member of the committee be requested by theday ofto ascertain and report any information which may be thought pertinent to the subject of enquiry— I agreed to accept this inserting before the general my special subject of enquiry the number of Slave owners and Sample moved to insert those words as an amendment to Gilmer’s amendment, which was carried 5 to 4. Davis voting upon this question, with Sample Giddings Morse and me— Gilmer, Burke, Burt and Ingersoll voting against us— The blank was filled with the first of February, Gilmer alone voting against it, and then the resolution as amended was carried by the same vote as my special object of enquiry, the number of Slave owners. My second resolution was then debated— Ingersoll moved to strike out some of the descriptive words, which was carried by his own vote, and then my resolution as amended was carried, Gilmer Burke and Burt only voting in the negative— Gilmer then moved that the journal of the Committee be reported to the house—he meant immediately to produce an explosion. I moved an amendment “with the final reports of the Committee”— My amendment was carried 7 to 2. Gilmer and Burt only voting against it and then the resolution as amended was adopted by an unanimous vote— The Committee then adjourned to the 1st of February at 10 O’Clock. In the house the rules were suspended to receive reports of Committees which would occasion no debate; and under this order Campbell, Chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, reported a petition from Lockport New-York, for a revision of the Laws of the District of Columbia with the unanimous opinion of that Committee that it came within the gag-rule, and should be returned, to the member who presented it, and he moved the previous question— I thought it was one of the petitions presented by me, and protested against the report of the Committee
Committee— The petition had been presented by Mr Giddings but was in substance the same with several others presented by me— Campbell to suppress all debate, in presenting the report had moved the previous question— Hunt of New York moved to lay the report and petition on the table; and that the petition be printed— This motion was rejected by yeas and nays, 51 to 118. a vote which shows of what stuff forty of the members who have voted to rescind the rule are made— I attempted to shew the direct falsehood of the report— The Speaker stop’d me, by saying that the previous question had been called and was not debatable. I then moved that the report be laid on the table The Speaker said that motion was not in order, having just been rejected by the house I said the motion was not the same, that having been to lay the report and petition on the table and to print the petition— Mine being to lay the report on the table— He said I might have moved a division of the question— It was now too late— Giddings raised a point of order which after some discussion the Speaker dismissed it by saying— The chair overrides the point of order—the previous question was carried, 83 to 36 and the report was adopted, by yeas and nays 118 to 60— The whole transaction was a signal example of the tyranny of the rule; and of the instability of popular assemblies, affected by sudden impulses, and cramped in the freedom of speech— Immediately after this exploit the report on the rules was taken up with Dromgoole’s motion to recommit, and E J. Black’s amendment with instructions to report the 25th. rule— Rhett made a speech of 40 minutes on the right of petition and Bidlack a third of a speech which was arrested in the midst of a sentence by the expiration of the morning hour, and the call for the orders of the day— Both these Speakers were under deep agitation. Rhett, eloquent pathetic and full of absurdities Bidlack, swelling with emotions, which he had neither compass of mind nor fluency of language to express and groaning between the upper and nether millstone of servility to the South and terror of his constituents. The house then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union R C Winthrop in the chair on the references of the parcels of the President’s message and Rathbun of New York and Thomasson hammered upon it till past four O’Clock, when the Committee rose, and the house adjourned— I commenced this evening a report to be submitted to the select Committee on the resolves of the Legislature of Massachusetts.

As I went this morning to the capitol I stop’d at the house of judge Cranch and enquired of his condition— His Son John came to the door, and said he was yet in a situation very critical, but with rather more favourable symptoms than the two preceding days. Before I left my house this morning Mr Farrar a young man from Vermont came to ask of me a certificate of his qualifications for a teacher; on the authority of strong certificates to that effect from William Slade, late a member of Congress and from the Senator from that State Phelps— I declined; but he sat and questioned me about my life and adventures for upwards of an hour. Mr Collins was a visitor of much the same description, but an emigrant from Ireland imported here some thirteen years since and lately a land surveyor under Governor Wilson of Ioway— He had a voluminous manuscript, to promote the election of Mr Clay as President, which he was about to publish and for which he was soliciting subscriptions. I said that when it should be published I would perhaps take a few copies— At the House among the trashy and intrusive abortions of business that are daily usurping the place of the morning hour, M’Kay chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, upon an appropriation bill of 40500 dollars, to supply a deficiency in the last years appropriation for the relief and protection of American Seamen— I objected, and said there would be ample time for the passage of this bill, after the expiration of the morning hour— I called for the order of the day—whereupon Joseph R. Ingersoll moved a suspension of the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— I asked for the yeas and nays, but they were refused— The house by a vote of more than two thirds went into Committee, Wilkins in the Chair, the Bill passed in Committee without opposition; was reported to the house without amendment, and passed in the space of a quarter of an hour— I then again called up the report on the rules, and Bidlack finished his hermaphrodite hour speech the main purport of which was that he had always voted for the gag in complacency to the South as long as they adhered together, but as they were now divided he was afraid he must leave them and vote the other way. He was followed by Belser of Alabama, till the expiration of the hour— The house then went into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the Message, which reported in part ten of Wise’s Resolutions and then rose—and the house adjourned.

I called twice this day at judge Cranch’s house first on my way to the Capitol, when I was informed that his condition was still extremely critical, but thought by his two physicians, Doctors Sewall and May more favourable than it had been for two preceding days— He is now in perfect possession of his mind, but was asleep and I would not disturb him— I saw his son Joseph Pearce who with his sister Mrs Rufus Dawes arrived this morning from New York— Pearce, recently married to Elizabeth de Windt, and Rufus Dawes reside together at New-York— My second call was after the adjournment of the House, when the judge was awake and I saw him— He was weaker than he had been in the morning, in a high fever, and seemed to entertain no hopes of recovery, but was calm and collected, full of gratitude to God for numberless blessings that he has enjoyed, through a long life, and ready to appear in the presence of his maker. He was much affected at seeing me grasped my hand with strong pressure at meeting and parting, and thanked me for the cheering words with which I endeavoured to revive his spirits— At the house after the reading of the journal, Mr Giddings, claimed as a right to make a statement of what he deemed a breach of privilege, by a violent attack, and false charge against him, published in the Globe of last Evening against him. Immediately the Slave representation set their faces against allowing Giddings to make any explanation— The Speaker decided that it was not a privileged question; which made it necessary for a two thirds vote to enable Giddings to defend his character against a cowardly assassin in a Newspaper published by the Printers of the House— Schenk moved a suspension of the rules for that purpose— The vote was 92 to 57. and the affirmative not carrying two thirds, Giddings was deprived of the freedom of Speech in self defence before the house— It was curious to hear several of the subterraneans vote against his having leave to explain and when they found the vote in his favour, change their votes to have the appearance on the record of having voted to hear him— Wilkins from the judiciary Committee reported a bill to extend to the district the act of Feby 1793 for the recovery of fugitive slaves and to repeal the district Law which authorizes the sale of free coloured people to pay for their jail-fees.— Saunders presented a minority report— Both were received; referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and ordered to be printed— The hour of debate on the Rules was occupied by Belser of Alabama, and Cobb of Georgia—and the rest of the day in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Winthrop in the chair on the Message, by Jameson of Missouri, till the adjournment—

I attended public worship this morning, in the Hall of the house of Representatives, with my nephew Isaac Hull Adams, and my granddaughter Mary Louisa— Before going to the Capitol we stop’d at judge Cranch’s house and they went in, to make enquiry of his state.— He was better, but still in imminent danger. The preacher at the Capitol was the Revd. Charles W. Denison, Chaplain of the Boston Bethel Union, and Editor of the Sheet Anchor, and his discourse was on the moral improvement of Seamen— He took for his text, if, he said any text was necessary, Isaiah 60.5.—the latter part of the verse—[“]because the abundance of the sea shall be converted unto thee, the forces of the gentiles shall come unto thee.” The style of Mr Denison’s oratory is colloquial, fluent and lively— The burden of his discourse was the importance of the Seamen as a distinct class of men, in human Society— He spoke of their influence upon the happiness and the morals of the rest of mankind—of the dangers and hardships incidental to their profession—of the generosity which is their peculiar and characteristic virtue—of the reckless profusion which is their besetting sin; and of the looseness of their moral principle which admonish those whose charge it is to teach the lessons of virtue to their fellow creatures, to use their utmost exertions to train them in the paths of virtue, and rally them to the standard of religion.— He told several familiar anecdotes pathetic and amusing, illustrative of the manners, and habits and propensities of Sailors, and named several distinguished men who have risen to honour and renown from the station of common sailors, among whom was Richard H. Dana, the author of two years before the mast. He spoke much of himself as the son of a professional mariner, and of a family chiefly of Seamen; and familiar with the manners, usages, opinions and sentiments congenial to the lives and fortunes of seafaring men— After the service was over, Mr Tinsley the chaplain came and introduced him to me He said that one of his motives in coming here was to prevail upon the Government to take for the use of the Navy-Yards a large subscription to a Sailor’s Newspaper of which he is the Editor; called the Sheet-Anchor. Philanthropy ending as usual in a job— I had a morning visit from Mr Slidell the democratic member from New-Orleans— After dinner at the second Presbyterian Church I heard Mr Knox, from 2 Corinthians 5.9. Wherefore we labour, that whether present or absent we may be accepted of him— It was the remnant of a discourse commenced this morning.

On my way to the Capitol this morning I stop’d at judge Cranch’s house, and was informed by his son John that he was so much better that they had now warm hopes of his recovery— In the house James H. Relfe of Missouri, moved to suspend the rules, for a motion to discharge the Committee of the whole from the 11th. resolution offered by Wise, for parceling out to Committees the President’s Message; at 3. O’Clock this afternoon— Ten of Wise’s Resolutions had been adopted in as many minutes in Committee, but had not been reported to the house. The 11th. opened the wide field of controversy on the question of internal improvements and has been debated now for nearly a month without seeming to approach a termination— Last Friday an attempt was made to take it out of Committee by the gag-process which failed. I then proposed that when the house should next take up in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union the partition message, they should report to the house in part the resolutions which they have adopted leaving the rest to be further discussed in Committee— This was accordingly done, and on Saturday the first ten of Wise’s Resolutions were reported to the house— Relfe however was impatient to dispose of the 11th. the apple of discord—the internal improvement of the Western waters and the Mississippi— Hence his motion to suspend the rules but it failed by Tellers 71 to 60— Next came a motion by Weller to reconsider a resolution offered by Patterson to riddle all the pigeon holes of the general Post-Office for information—to reduce the rates of Postage, and to abolish the franking privilege— This is a notion which has recently taken possession of the brains of the Northern Postage payers, and they are clamorous for reduction of the rates, and for the abolition of the franking privilege— In the debate of this day, the most important question of the concern was not touched at-all— The subject was postponed till to morrow— The states, were called through for Resolutions, and was prolific of yankee notions— I offered a call on the President for the correspondence with the government of Texas, concerning the complaint of President Houston, that our troops had broken up their Snively expedition against Santa Fe— Objection was made to my Resolution, and it lies over. E. J. Black gave notice that when the bill for organizing the Oregon territory shall come up, he will move an additional section for the provisional annexation of Texas to the United States— Cave Johnson introduced a bill to repeal the duties on Salt and the fishing bounties, and moved a reconsideration of a resolution looking to an appropriation for removing snags from the Mississippi river.

Mr Frye came this morning and introduced Mr Walker of Cincinnati, Ohio; who says that he saw and heard, and shook hands with me there; but whose person I did not recollect. At the house, there was a remarkable developement of a new phasis in the conflict of internal improvement— The day before yesterday came the intelligence from St Louis, Missouri, that a large Steamer, called the Shepherdess from New-Orleans struck a snag within 3 miles of St. Louis, and sunk instantly with the loss of from 40 to 100 lives— Thomasson of Kentucky, yesterday took advantage of this incident to move an instruction to the Committee of Ways and Means, to report a Bill making an appropriation for removing obstructions in the Mississippi and its tributary rivers— Thomasson made a pathetic speech about the disaster of the shepherdess, and his resolution passed without opposition, but Cave Johnson afterwards moved a reconsideration of it, and brought up again the same interminable dispute about the constitutional power of Congress, which has been already drained to the dregs in Committee of the whole on the President’s message— Wilkins of Pittsburgh had closed the debate of yesterday on the question of reconsideration— James B Bowlin of Missouri led it off in an hour speech this morning in the course of which he complained that the Committee of Ways and means had struck out the sum presented in the estimates for improvements on the western rivers Joseph R. Ingersoll and David L. Seymour of New-York, members of the Committee knew nothing of this crippling of the Estimates; but Weller of Ohio also a member of the Committee confirmed it— Andrew Stewart followed in an hour speech, urging Cave Johnson to modify his motion for reconsideration so as to refer Thomasson’s resolution of instructions, not to the committee of Ways and Means, but to the Committee of Roads and Canals— Stewart plunged into the Tariff and the Presidential election question and charged Van Buren with holding all internal improvements beyond the powers of Congress.— Stewart worried out his hour frequently interrupted by insulting comments and charges of falsehood by M’Connell, and frequently called to order by the Speaker for irrelevancy— Joseph R. Ingersoll followed him in a flowery courtly speech Kennedy of Indiana gave a new specimen of his brutal insolence, and Holmes of Charleston a specimen of his cunning casuistry. He announced an unanswerable legal argument to prove that Congress had the power to spend money for the improvement of the Mississippi, but of no other river. His authority was the Ordinance for the Northwestern Territory—

My Catarrhal cough has returned upon with fresh severity.— I went to bed at Midnight and soon after three this morning was roused by a fit of coughing, for relief from which I was obliged to leave my bed for a few minutes, after which I returned to it, and broken sleep till six— I sent for Doctor Thomas; stated my case and asked his advice— He prescribed 3 pills a day—Morning Noon and Night. I went to the Capitol this morning at 11; and borrowed from the Law Library, the 2d. volume of Haggard’s admiralty reports; containing page 94. the case of the Slave Grace, decided by Lord Stowell in 1827. immediately before the abolition of Slavery in the British West India Colonies—by Act of Parliament— I wanted also the 20th. Volume of Howell’s State-trials, containing the case of the Negro Somersett—but the book was taken out by the Senator Rufus Choate— I found the house in Session, and Weller discoursing upon Cave Johnson’s motion to reconsider Thomasson’s resolution instructing the Committee of Ways and Means to bring in a bill appropriating money to remove obstructions in the Mississippi river and its tributaries— Weller was violent and abusive upon Stewart, and charged him directly with falsehood in his statements of Van Buren’s doctrines concerning internal improvements— Stewart replied by repeating the statements declaring that he would prove them from the Letters of Mr Van Buren himself. After a string of common-places from Thomas Smith of Indiana, Samuel F. Vinton of Ohio took the floor and in a plain sensible and moderate speech placed the question its true foundations and used up the pettifogging sophistry of Holmes. John J. Hardin of Illinois came next, and then D. D. Barnard with an argument of irresistible force, but with a stern and peremptory tone and manner which irritates even those whom it convinces— This is the drop of and in Mr Barnard’s Oratory, which curdles his eloquence— The cogency and self confidence of his argument, stung the brutal temper of Kennedy the Indiana blacksmith, who grossly insulted him, without being rebuked by the Speaker. Cave Johnson finally got the floor, and retained it unfairly—moved an amendment that the Committee of Ways and Means enquire into the expediency of the appropriation, and called for the previous question, which was carried, and the amendment and resolution were adopted— Mr and Mrs Grinnell were here this Evening— Also Mrs. Thornton—and Mrs Talbot with her daughter.

Immediately after the reading of the Journal we had in the house one of those amiable exhibitions of good nature which the chattel representation are so much in the habit of displaying— The Colonization Society had obtained the use of the hall, and had held a meeting there last Tuesday evening. Not having finished their business then they adjourned their meeting to this evening; but the Speaker was scrupulous about the exercise of his power to dispose of the Hall, and insisted that Society must again obtain the use of the Hall, by vote of the house— Before there was a Quorum formed, Irvin of Pennsylvania, moved that the Society should have the use of the Hall— Edward J. Black of Georgia objected, saying that he regarded them all as abolitionists— Irvin explained and moved a suspension of the rules to enable him to offer the Resolution— The question was first taken by rising 76 in favour of suspending the rule—less than 20 against it, but no quorum voting— Black persisted in his purpose— A call of the house was moved and refused—a call of the yeas and nays was made and refused. At last a member moved to adjourn, and called the yeas and nays— This brought the house to— On the motion to adjourn the vote was 1 to 158. Then on the motion to suspend the rules the vote by yeas and nays was 127 to 47. and the Resolution was adopted without an adverse voice— A full hour was consumed in this miserable chicanery by Black and it is a sample of his daily manifestations of temper— There was some discussion of a resolution offered by Patterson, from Rochester, New-York, of enquiry upon the Postmaster general concerning the abuses of the franking privilege, the reconsideration of which had been moved— It was finally laid over for debate— There are many memorials and petitions calling for a reduction of the rates of postage, and the abolition or restriction of the franking privilege, but it is apparent that neither the Postmaster general nor the Chairman of the Committee intend to make any change— An hour of debate was allowed upon the report on the rules, occupied by Cobb of Georgia to finish his speech and by Charles Hudson to commence his— Then Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Winthrop in the Chair upon the Message and the Western waters. Andrew Stewart occupied the floor till the adjournment.

Met in the chamber of the Committee of foreign affairs, the select Committee on copy-rights— Present Winthrop, Leonard, Bowlin, Black and Adams. It was near 11. before there was a quorum— Ingersoll came in, after the Committee had adjourned— Absent Herrick of Maine, Chapman of Alabama, and Emery D Potter of Ohio While we were waiting for a quorum Winthrop read a long memorial from Nahum Capen of Boston urging expediency and Justice of an international copy-right Law. Black came in a little before 11. stayed but a few minutes and said he wanted to make a Report against the Bill— The Committee adjourned to this day fortnight, the 2d. of February—after agreeing that Winthrop should report a Resolution to print Capen’s Memorial and five or six additional Sections which Ingersoll proposes as amendments to his bill— In the house Vance Chairman of the Committee of Claims moved a suspension of the rules for the reception of reports from Committees such as would give rise to no debate which was carried against my remonstrance, and several reports were received, among which was that of R. C. Winthrop for printing Nahum Capen’s Memorial which was adopted. I enquired of Hopkins chairman of the Committee on Post-Offices and Post-roads, whether that Committee would report a Bill to reduce the rates of Postage, and if so when it might be expected. He answered that the Committee had taken the subject into consideration, but had come to no conclusion, concerning it: nor did he know when they would report but probably in the course of a few weeks— The debate on Dromgoole’s motion to recommit, the report on the rules and Black’s amendment to instruct the Committee to report the 25th rule was resumed, and Hudson finished his hour, followed by Romulus M Saunders who clings to the rule with the grasp of death. At the expiration of the hour, it being private bill day, Cave Johnson moved the suspension of the rules to go into Committee of the whole, on the state of the Union upon the President’s Message which was carried Weller of Ohio made an hour speech of more brutal fury than I ever heard, all pointed personally at Andrew Stewart, cheered and edged on by the Van Buren majority.— Brinkerhoff of Ohio followed but soon became faint; the Committee rose and the house adjourned— Schenk told me that Weller was expelled from college for obscenity and profanity— I walked home from the Capitol— Mr Moseley spent part of the Evening with us.

Nearly three hours of my time extinguished by sleep refreshing to the time worn, care worn, diseased and exhausted body, but at the expense of the active energies of the Soul— I am pressed with the task of preparing the minority report for the Committee on the Resolves of the Massachusetts Legislature so that I find it almost impossible to keep up this Diary with the current of Time— I had hoped this morning for some leisure to make progress in this work, but I had only time for a call at the Bank of the Metropolis for my book, which I had left there to be balanced, when the hour summoned me to the house— Hughes of Missouri offered a Resolution to instruct the Committee on the Territories to enquire into the expediency of reporting as soon as possible a joint resolution requesting the President to give notice to the British Government that after 12 months the Government of the United States will annul and abrogate the Convention of 6 September 1827. Williams objected to this resolution that there was already one of the same import referred to the Committee of foreign affairs— The yeas and nays were called and refused on the motion to suspend the rules; but the resolution was rejected— Wentworth of Illinois presented a Memorial against the annexation of Texas to the United States; but said one of the memorialists had written to him that if there was any danger that England should get Texas; they were willing the United States should have it in preference— Cave Johnson moved to go into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, on the references of the President’s Message. I remonstrated against this claiming the morning hour for the discussion of the report on the rules; but in vain— The majority of the house are playing a game of fast and loose with me on this subject, and desert me whenever any opportunity is afforded them so to do— They went into Committee of the whole, Winthrop in the Chair; and jabbered about the western waters, and in struggles to refuse Stewart the liberty to reply to the scandalous and insolent attacks of Weller upon him yesterday. Every species of chicanery was used to deprive him of this privilege; and when granted he replied under continual interruptions and calls to order, from the majority and repeated insults and defiances to fight from M’Connell.— At two, the voting on the reference of the western waters commenced. Thomasson’s amendment to Wise’s Resolution, and all the other amendments were rejected and the original resolution of reference to the Committee of Commerce was adopted— The resolution to refer the notice of the Smithsonian bequest, to a select Committee was amended by Burke’s motion to refer it to the joint Committee on the library. The Committee reported and the house adjourned— Holmes by way of bravado immediately after Stewart concluded his speech had made a motion to instruct the judiciary Committee to enquire into the expediency of repealing the Law against duelling, which was received with a shout of laughter.

Light snow, all the morning. I attended public worship at the Capitol, where the Revd. Justin Edwards said to be from Boston preached a discourse upon the sanctity of the Sabbath, from Mark 2.27. “The Sabbath was made for man.”— This question about keeping the Sabbath holy, as a day of rest is one of the numerous religious and political excitements which keep the free people of this union in perpetual agitation.— They seem to be generated by the condition of the country—in a state of profound peace— There are in this country as in all others a certain proportion of restless and turbulent spirits, poor, unoccupied, ambitious, who must always have something to quarrel about with their neighbours— These people are the authors of religious revivals— They formed in the days of Washington’s administration the germ of the Jacobin clubs— During the last War with Great Britain, they generated the Washington benevolent Societies and Peace Societies. In later times, they have bred the Masonic and anti-masonic Societies the Temperance Societies, the, Colonization, abolition and anti-Slavery Societies, and they are now beating the drum and blowing the trumpet for a holy Sabbath Society— A numerous Convention is already advertised to promote the cause, and Mr Edwards has come to preach for it in the Representative Hall— After announcing his text he said that the word Sabbath meant rest, and that it was one of the ten commandments written by the finger of God upon stone, as Laws for all men, that after every six days of labour there should be one day of rest.— He dwelt exclusively upon the commandment, which he said was a law of nature for man and for beast who could perform more labour enjoy more health and live longer upon six days of labour, and one of rest than upon seven successive days of labour— His illustrations were numerous and his zeal intense and evidently sincere; but he took no notice of the exposition of the true meaning of the commandment when his own disciples were charged with the violation of it— Isaac Hull, and my Granddaughter went with me to the Hall— Mr Tustin the Chaplain of the Senate was with the preacher, and gave out and sung the hymn— After the service I returned the visit of Mr Daniel Webster at his house and had a conversation with him of upwards of an hour— After dinner I attended at the Presbyterian Church, and heard a Mr Smith from New York discourse upon the sufferings of Jesus, the marred countenance—the man of sorrows and acquainted with grief.

In my earnestness to recover the encroachment of time upon my Diary record, and yet make progress in my report to be ready before the first of February, I was this day belated half an hour in my attendance at the house— I found it in Session— It was the day for the reception of petitions, and the Speaker who had begun with the Territory of Ioway had already reached the State of Ohio in his call— Douglass of Indiana had made a report from the Committee of Elections had made a report on the contested elections, and Garret Davis had promised a minority report— Elmer the ostensible chairman of the Committee had given notice that he would call up the report for consideration to-morrow, two weeks— Giddings presented several anti-slavery and abolition-petitions; among the rest one from 381 citizens of Hampshire County, Massachusetts, praying Congress by law to prohibit the officers of the United States from assisting to arrest persons suspected of being fugitives from Slavery There was much fluttering among the Slavers The Speaker decided that this petition was not within the 25th. rule— From which decision Black of Georgia appealed— I called for the yeas and nays— Saunders attempted to raise the question of reception, but the Speaker said it was too late— Jameson enquired if laying the appeal on the table would carry the petition with it— The Speaker said no— Wilkins said there was just such a petition referred to the Committee on the judiciary— Payne moved to lay the appeal on the table carried 113 ayes He then made the question of reception and Cave Johnson moved to lay that on the table— This is the wooden nutmeg form of rejecting a petition, without refusing to receive it— The question to lay on the table was lost 85 to 87 and then the question to receive was lost 85 to 86. In the interval between the two takings of yeas and nays Freedom lost two votes Slavery gained one, and the majority was changed— Beardsley presented a petition praying for the repeal of the act of February 1793 for catching fugitive Slaves— Thompson moved the question of reception and Weller moved to lay it on the table— Beardsley moved a call of the house—and Hopkins moved to adjourn, and it was carried— Another slip of the rattlesnake Slavery from the grasp of Freedom— I dined at General Almonte’s the Mexican Minister, with a company of Ladies and Gentlemen—Mr D. D. Barnard—Mr and Mrs. B. Ogle Tayloe—Mr and Mrs Gales and Miss Walker—Mr and Mrs Seaton, and their daughter—young Yturbide and his two sisters; Mr Cos secretary of the Mexican legation, Miss Cutts, and sundry others— My wife and daughter Mary were invited, but declined— A magnificent dinner— Dancing after.

I had received last evening a note from Mr Daniel R Goodloe of North-Carolina requesting an interview with me for which I appointed ten O’Clock this morning. He came accordingly with a manuscript of 26 folio pages, of which he said he was the author which he was desirous of publishing in a pamphlet; and of which he wished me to give my opinion.— He pointed out to me a page or two, which I read, and which contained the essence of his Essay, and left the manuscript with me, to call again to morrow— I promised to read the manuscript in the interval, and to give him my opinion of the expediency of publishing it— A poor Negro came in a state almost of distraction, to implore me to save his wife from being sold away. I asked him how I could do that? He said by purchasing her myself; for 400 dollars— I told him that was impossible. The poor fellow went away in despair— Two Young men, one named M’Rae, and the other Hamilton, came with a Letter of introduction from John G. Palfrey, now Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. The Letter is dated at Cambridge, and they were students at the Law School there— Immediately after the reading of the journal, Charles J. Ingersoll chairman of the Committee of foreign affairs instantly moved a suspension of the Rules to receive Reports from Committees— Cave Johnson suggested to him to confine his motion to one hour, to which he readily assented— Their object was to supersede the debate on the rules and smuggle it out of the way. I knew it would be in vain to oppose the movement directly and the suspension was carried without opposition— Holmes, Chairman of the Committee of Commerce asked from that Committee, leave to employ a Clerk— Half an hour of piddling debate and the motion laid on the table. C. J. Ingersoll reported from the Committee of foreign Affairs against a Resolution offered by Robert Dale Owen, and referred to that Committee—to request the President to give 12 months notice to the British Government that we will abrogate the agreement of mutual occupation of the Oregon territory— The report of the Committee is that it is inexpedient for Congress to take any action whatever upon the subject at present— No sooner was the Resolution of the Committee read than Owen came out with a set speech against it, and as the hour drew to a close when he moved a second suspension of the rules to go into Committee of the whole on the Union, for him to continue his speech—this barely failed for want of two thirds 111 to 63. I called the order of the morning hour— Saunders finished and Winthrop began.

I cannot keep pace in my Diary with the lapse of time, and was obliged to break off my record in the middle—yesterday— This morning Mr Goodloe called on me— I had read carefully his manuscript, and expressed to him the very favourable opinion of it which I entertained. And I candidly made to him some remarks on what I thought deficient in his illustrations— Mr Lewis Johnson was here, and gave me three checks of the Bank of the Metropolis, each for 50 dollars payable to my order, on the Merchant’s Bank at Boston for which I gave him 3 receipts signed by Norton Quincy Thaxter—as received from Lewis Johnson administrator to the Estate of William Otis—one for Mr Thaxter himself—one for Felipe Ximenes and Ellen M. C. Ximenes, and one for Josephine O. Cogley.— These, with Mr Thaxter’s wife, are the children of Nathaniel Otis, one of William Otis’s brothers, by a Spanish West India woman whom he married in the Island of Cuba— I had received the receipts a few days since in a Letter from Mr Thaxter. At the house immediately after the reading of the journal, I called for the order of the day, Hopkins made an attempt to set it aside but failed. Garret Davis made a minority report from the Committee of elections on the question of the members elected by general ticket from the four States. Campbell moved the printing of 5000 copies of both reports— But the Speaker said the motion was not in order, and objection was made. His motion was not received— The report on the rules was resumed— Winthrop finished his hour speech; an excellent one, but repeatedly interrupted by the addle headed blunders of Rhett, about a precedent from Hatsell in 1665.— Winthrop was followed by W. W. Payne of Alabama in support of the rule— As he was closing half a dozen members started up, among whom the Speaker recognized Joseph A. Wright of Indiana, who began in so low and tame a tone of voice that I could not hear what he said. But the Speaker immediately told him the morning hour had expired. Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, Campbell of South-Carolina in the chair— Robert Dale Owen, the Scotch Atheist finished his hour speech for abrogating the Oregon joint occupation Convention— Thomasson just hinted objections. In the meantime I had gone into the Senate chamber and asked Mr Choate for the 20th. volume of Howell’s State trials which he afterwards sent me. On my return to the house I found Wentworth roaring like a bull buffalo about the Oregon territory; but nobody followed him— Parmenter acting as chairman of the Naval Committee called up the bill for authorising the President to transfer Naval Appropriations, which started an amusing debate, which came to no conclusion— C. J. Ingersoll gave notice of a negro catch pole bill— I spent the Evening with Mary and Isaac Hull, at Mr Cutts’s—

Mr Goodloe came again this morning and had further conversation with me concerning the publication of his manuscript. He had yesterday written me a note requesting to see me again on the subject, and brought with him this morning a couple of pages, which he thought would supply the deficiency which I thought necessary to complete his Essay.— I thought there was still something wanting, but that his work was ingenious; his views in some respects new to me, and well worthy of publication— Brown the poor man for whom at the last Session I had procured the passage of a bill in the house, which failed in the Senate, came with a copy of the Bill, and of the Report of the Committee of the house in his favour, came to request that I would call it up again in the house, which I promised to do—and did— On my way to the house I stop’d at the Patriotic Bank, and found that my draft on the Frederic Hotel Stock had been paid, and was credited, with a small charge at Frederic for collection to me as Executor of Thomas B. Johnson\, at the Patriotic Bank— As I do owe a credit to Mr Johnson’s estate, I left it thus charged though received as administrator to my son John, whose Estate is indebted to me. At the house immediately after the reading of the journal, I called for the order of the day— But Lucius Quintius Cincinnatus Elmer accidental chairman of the Committee of Elections, presented a report on the contested election of Goggin and Gilmer, closing with a Resolution declaring Gilmer duly-elected.— He moved that the report should be referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union and printed— And he moved that the Memorials presented to the Committee on their first meeting by both parties should be printed— Goggin is said to be sick at home— His friend Willoughby Newton objected to the printing of his memorial because it rested on a state of facts which Goggin had reason to believe true, but disproved by subsequent evidence. The motive for printing it now, being to prejudice the public mind against Goggin at home—in his own district. This gave rise to an acrimonious debate of 3 hours, the result of which was by yeas and nays to order the printing of both memorials, and also of the testimony. Schenk obtained leave to make a minority report on the same case— I then struggled to get up the report on the rules, But the house refused to take them or any thing else up and adjourned— Dr Thomas was here this evening and prescribed for my cough— Mr Grinnell and Richard Peters were also here—

I received this morning a Letter from my Son, enclosing one from Petty Vaughan, to Mr Curtis and me as Executors of Ward Nicholas Boylston, and a power of Attorney from his as assignee, by a deed of assignment of 1. Feby 1824. from George Lee, surviving assignee of Lane and Co. to Mr Curtis and me jointly and severally as Executors of W. N. Boylston, to receive 979 dollars, of unclaimed dividends on United States stocks, standing on the books in the Office of Register of the Treasury, standing in the name of George Lee, George Erving and Thomas Latham— The discovery of this credit was made by the same Charles D. Lewis of New-York who gave me notice last October of the dividend standing on the same books in the name of my father— In the present case Mr Lewis applied to Alfred Latham son of Thomas Latham; deceased, but who had been the last survivor of the assignees of Lane and Co. in whose bankruptcy Thomas Boylston was involved and whose assignment was by then finally assigned to Ward N. Boylston— Alfred Latham referred Charles D. Lewis to Petty Vaughan who consequently sent this power to Mr Curtis and me, and agreed if we should recover the sum of 979 dollars, Mr Lewis should receive 100 dollars of the prize—he had demanded 25 per cent— I went immediately to the Register’s Office with the power from Petty Vaughan—the entry on the books was immediately found and I received a check on the Bank of the Metropolis, for 979 dollars 78 cents— They retained at the Office the power from P. Vaughan. These transactions furnish a theme upon which I would gladly comment, but I must go ahead— In the house Charles J. Ingersoll bolted a whole day’s debate, by calling on the Speaker to turn out of the house Nathan Sargent, Reporter for the United States Gazette of Philadelphia under the signature of Oliver Oldschool, for what he charged to be a false report, but which was an exactly true report of the scene in the house last Tuesday—when he asked the question whether I was the author of the Massachusetts Resolutions of last Winter against the Slave Representation, and without answering him I turned away and called for the yeas and nays.— Ingersoll made no motion, and there was no question before the house—and when called on to specify the part of the report which he charged with falsehood—he said, the whole— I declared to the house that the motive imputed to me by the reporter for not answering the question was true—that I did consider the question as a piece of impertinence, and therefore did not answer it— After three hours of debate, without any question before the house, and numerous struggles to get rid of it, baffled by the joint partiality and imbecility of the Speaker, it was at last disposed of by a large vote of indefinite postponement. I then called up the report on the rules; but the house would not second me. It was postponed till to-morrow—and the house adjourned. Mr D. P. King and Dr Brewer were here this Evening. The doctor goes for Boston to-morrow.

Mr Sargent called on me this morning to thank me for having interposed yesterday, against the brutal and cowardly assault of Charles J. Ingersoll, upon his character, in which, afterwards Wise, with equal baseness joined. The day before this sally of Ingersoll, Weller, with Payne and Belser of Alabama, aiding, abetting and edging him on, had knocked down beaten and wounded another Reporter and Letter writer, named Shriver, for a Report in the Baltimore Patriot of Weller’s infamous treatment of Stewart last week— And some days before, Jones the Speaker had displaced Mr Leavitt from the place assigned to him. The simple truth is that the ruffians of the house cannot bear the exposure of their villainies by the press, and they combine with the Speaker to silence or smother its voice.— In the midst of the Babel talk of Charles J. Ingersoll yesterday Cave Johnson offered a new rule, that no Reporters shall be admitted within the Hall, except those for the city papers— That was not in order, but he gave notice that he would offer it this day, which he did— Edward J. Black of Georgia, moved as an amendment a rule for the appointment of Reporters to be Officers of the house; and prescribing in ridiculous detail what they shall report— The Speaker did not favour either Cave Johnson’s or Black’s resolution; the object of both of them being to strangle the freedom of debate in the house and of the press out of it— Wise presented his minority report from the Committee on the Rules—signed he said by two members—(himself and Chapman—) The report was ordered to be printed— Charles J. Ingersoll wanted to say something about this minority report, but was not permitted. The report on the rules was taken up; Joseph A. Wright of Indiana made a feeble half hour speech against the gag-rule, and William H. Stiles began a long concoted and elaborate speech in support of it.— The house went into Committee of the whole on private bills, and passed one into the house; besides debating nearly an hour whether certain bills on that calendar were private or public bills. Then followed a long debate on a bill, reported by Parmenter from the Naval Committee, for the relief of the widows and orphans of the Officers, Seamen and Marines of the Schooner Grampus lost at Sea— Levy the delegate from Florida moved to add those of the Sea-Gull— The debate continued, Gilmer in the chair till past 4. O’Clock, and the Committee rose without reporting, and the house adjourned. I dined with Mr Grinnell and Mr Winthrop at their lodgings. Mr Bates the Senator, and George Evans of Maine are of the mess— In the Evening Mr and Mrs Grinnell went with me to the Amateur Charity concert

After the plenteous, indulgence of gastronomy of yesterday’s dinner, and the liberal disposal of the evening at the amateur charity concert, I rose this morning with the Sun, less troubled with my cough, more refreshed and more vigorous than I have been for many days. St. John’s church which has for several months undergoing repairs was this day first reopened for public worship, and Mrs John Adams, with her daughter Mary Louisa, and Isaac H. Adams attended the morning service there— I rode to the Hall of the house of Representatives, and there heard Mr Tinsley the Chaplain of the house, preach from Romans 10.10. “For with the heart, man believeth unto righteousness: and with the mouth, confession is made unto salvation”— He said he should confine his remarks to the first clause of the verse, and his discourse would be on Faith— The text was extremely well selected— The idea that Faith commences in the heart and terminates in righteousness presents a new view of the subject, prolific of illustration— If I can ever find the time I will write a second Lecture on Faith—in elucidation of this view— That Faith is always an impulse of the heart, and that its tendency is always to a virtuous conclusion— Apply the principle to belief in the existence of God—to the immortality of the Soul, and to the doctrines of Christianity— All this tends to righteousness— But apply it to the divinity of Jesus Christ, to the Trinity; to transubstantiation to the doctrine of an infallible head to the church—in all this there is no tendency to righteousness— Mr Tinsley did not take this view of his text— His sermon was very short and superficial rather telling his auditory what Faith is not, than what it is— He said that mere belief in Christ, and even in his religion was not Faith—for the devils believe and tremble &c— The hall was very thin, and there was a light snow, which continued through the day and cleared off in the evening— After dinner, I attended at the Presbyterian Church, where Mr Knox preached, I believe from Romans 13.11 “And that, knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep”— Mr Knox is earnest and impressive— He gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday in the afternoon— Mr John Connell, and Mr Richard Cutts spent part of this evening here. The cold weather has got into the house, and pinches my fingers, so as to disable them for writing, without extreme difficulty— Time still sweeps along— How shall my record keep pace with him?

Mr Gilchrist came to make enquiries about the claims and the bequests and the deeds of land by John Stokes, and his collateral kindred with which I have been so often, and so uselessly conversant for the last ten or twelve years, and I gave him all the information upon the subject which my Memory could furnish— It appears that one of the Stokes’s has undertaken to give conveyances of the land, for which he has received equivalents, and the validity of which is under investigation— Brown the claimant of military bounty land was also here, and I told him that his claim with the bill which passed the house in his favour at the last Session were before the Committee of invalid pensions— At the house, the day was consumed in the call for Resolutions, beginning with Florida, and ending with Maine— One of the first was by R. Smith of Illinois proposing to instruct one of the Committees to enquire into the expediency of having a distribution of the biennial Register; which at my suggestion he modified into a call on the Secretary of State for the reasons why the biennial register has not been delivered on the first week in Jany according to the joint-resolution for its publication, which was adopted— Julius W. Blackwell moved that from and after the first Monday in February the hour of daily meeting should be 11. O’Clock— Black of Georgia moved as an amendment 3. p.m. Campbell moved a joint resolution of amendment to the Constitution, taking away the power of exclusive legislation over the district of Columbia, and for receding the two parts of the District to the two States of Virginia and Maryland— Ellis moved a Resolution for closing the Session on the 20th. of May. Cranston moved as amendment the first of May; and half the day was consumed in struggles to get up a debate and vote on these proposals which every soul present knows can come to nothing.— Hale moved to instruct the military committee to report a bill to abolish the military academy at West Point— There were as usual, swarms of embryo and abortion resolutions, without purpose of utility or chance of success.— Adjourned, shortly after 4.— I dined at Dr Thomas’s with a company of 17 persons Mrs Hill, Mr and Mrs Charles Hill, and Miss Ellen Ann Hill— Mr and Mrs Hutchins, Miss Bernabeu, Miss Yturbide, Miss Stewart, General Scott, Captain Casey, Mr Ringgold and others— Evening at Mr F. Markoe’s, a Meeting of the members of the National Institute, at which I was chairman— It was voted again to hold the anniversary Meeting of several days in April next.

I am yet cramped by the continuance of the cold, somewhat abated by the ascent of the thermometer to the temperature of snow— Between the preparation of my report on the Massachusetts Resolves, and keeping time with my daily record the labour is more than Herculean, and my correspondence is almost entirely suspended— Five days in the week the Report of the Committee on the rules is the first business in order to be transacted in the house; and if I were to be absent one day when it would be called up, it would be laid upon the table without redemption— When I call it up scarce a day passes but some dirty trick is devised to postpone the taking of the question— This day Stiles of Georgia finished his hour speech, and 23 minutes were left of the morning hour— A. Johnson of Tennessee another Slave holder obtained the floor and said he wished to deliver his whole speech at once, and so he moved to postpone the further consideration of the subject till to-morrow, against which I remonstrated in vain— I hear it said that they intend to keep off the question upon the rules till after my report upon the Resolves of the Massachusetts Legislature— This policy is a hint for the modification of mine.— The house went into committee of the whole on the state of the Union John Campbell in the chair, upon the bill reported by Parmenter from the Naval Committee, authorising the Secretary of the Navy to transfer 200000 dollars from one head of specific appropriation to another— Say from pay to repairs of ships.— Cave Johnson led off an opposition to the bill, seconded by Hopkins, and then by Barnard— An Amendment, and an amendment to the amendment were moved; till it called up Wise, in aid of Parmenter— Wise delivered a dissertation upon the usefulness and glory of the navy; with a general panegyric upon its officers, and especially upon the midshipmen and passed midshipmen, all of whom he pronounced fully qualified to be Admirals. All which was mere whip’d syllabub— The amendment, and amendment to the amendment were both rejected, and the bill was reported to the house, when it was ordered to be engrossed—the question upon its passage came up; and a motion to adjourn prevailed— I had a long evening visit from Mr Bache who has been appointed superintendent of the Coast survey in place of F. Hassler

The cold continues, and with it my difficulties to keep pace in writing with time— I brought up my diary, but fall into arrears with my report on the Massachusetts Resolves—the subject as usual widening as I proceed. Mr John Connell was here this morning to request once more my aid to get through the bill for the relief of the heirs of Robert Fulton—a desperate concern. Mr Lewis Johnson came, and I returned to him the three receipts of Norton Quincy Thaxter for the three checks on the Merchant’s Bank, which I have not yet found time to enclose to him— I hurried up to the Capitol to be there at the meeting of the house— The report on the rules was immediately taken up, and Andrew Johnson a new member from Tennessee made an hour speech in support of the gag-rule. and especially abusive upon me. So they all are.— I am compelled not only to endure it with seeming insensibility, but to forbear so far as I can restrain myself from all reply— This man took at once the ground that Congress have no power to abolish Slavery in the District of Columbia, because the Legislatures of Virginia and Maryland had no such power before their cessions of the two parts of the district to the United States— All the arguments of the speech were upon a level with this.— When he finished William C. M’Causlen took the floor—but the hour had expired and there was a call for the orders of the day.— But Edmund Burke, moved that the Speaker should be directed to adjourn the house at two O’Clock— There was some objection made and he withdrew his motion— Another member renewed it, and it was adopted without opposition— It was to allow members to attend the obsequies of Mrs Redding, wife of John R. Redding another of the spurious members from New-Hampshire— I went in to the Library to look into the Madison papers. They had only one copy of the work there, and that was in use by Mr Rhett. They borrowed it for me for five minutes, and I found in two of the volumes, the Leaves doubled down ready to my hand; but Mr Rhett could not spare the book, and on my way home I stop’d at Taylor’s and bought the book. Isaac Munro, with John G. Proud and his Son, brought me a gold headed cane, with a flattering Letter from the banner Clay Committee at Baltimore— I was extremely grateful for the Letter and the compliment but declined accepting the cane.
